summary: This is a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) Program Statement (P5264.08) detailing the national policy and procedures for inmate telephone privileges within BOP institutions and contract facilities. It outlines regulations for telephone list preparation, call monitoring, limitations, and security procedures, including specific guidance for pretrial inmates and those with 'Serious Telephone Abuse' designations. This document is a Bureau of Prisons policy (P5264.08) detailing procedures for inmate telephone use, monitoring, restrictions, and expenses. It outlines rules for unmonitored attorney calls, monitored non-ITS telephones, and circumstances under which the Warden can impose telephone restrictions. It is a standard operating procedure, not specific to any individual case.

keyFacts: This BOP policy document establishes national procedures for inmate telephone use, including call monitoring, list management, and security restrictions.
The policy explicitly states that inmate telephone calls are subject to monitoring to preserve institutional security, with the exception of properly placed calls to an attorney.
Inmates with a 'Serious Telephone Abuse' Public Safety Factor (PSF) are generally prohibited from using the Inmate Telephone System (ITS), with limited exceptions.
The document details procedures for pretrial, holdover, and detainee inmates, noting that the 'Serious Telephone Abuse' PSF applies to sentenced inmates but not automatically to pretrial inmates.
The policy allows inmates to include attorneys on their telephone lists but notes such calls are subject to monitoring unless specific procedures for unmonitored attorney calls are followed.
This is a general Bureau of Prisons policy manual (P5264.08) dated January 24, 2008, governing inmate telephone use.
The policy details strict procedures for monitoring inmate calls, with exceptions for unmonitored calls to attorneys which inmates must pay for.
It authorizes Wardens to impose telephone restrictions on inmates with a 'Public Safety Factor' for Serious Telephone Abuse or those pending investigation for telephone abuse.
The document is signed by Harley G. Lappin, who was the Director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons at the time.
The text is a standard operating procedure and contains no specific references to Jeffrey Epstein, his case, or any related individuals.
